MVA. Plaintiff suffered torn ligament in her shoulder. Continues to suffer pain 5 years after accident. Plaintiff had to switch line of work from one she enjoyed. She feels depressed and has given up active lifestyle and social life.

Defendant placed defamatory advertisements about his former lawyer, the plaintiff, in local newspapers and on a website. The wide circulation, repeated running, and internet accessibility of the comments were considered in assessing damages. The award included aggravated damages.

Plaintiff left defendant’s insurance brokerage and began to work for another insurance broker. Defendant called plaintiff’s new employer and falsely claimed that the plaintiff had signed a non-competition clause and had stolen property from the defendant. The plaintiff’s reputation was key to her professional success and the defendant was intentionally malicious; he tried to victimize a professional subordinate.

Orthopedic surgeon gave negligent treatment of broken femur resulting in additional surgery and osteomyelitis. Plaintiff will have recurring osteomyelitis throughout life. Damages awarded only for harm after negligent treatment. Appeal affirmed trial decision.

Defendant landlord called police multiple times on the plaintiff and pressed charges which were ultimately dismissed. Plaintiff spent time in detention centre and found the experience shocking and horrific, he lost weight, his hair turned white, his health has deteriorated, and his reputation was damaged.

case_name: Elliot v. Waterloo Region Police Services
comments: Defendant police officers conducted an illegal search of Plaintiff’s home while he was out. Upon his return, Plaintiff was falsely arrested and unlawfully detained. Despite informing officers he had an injured arm, the arm was handcuffed and Plaintiff denied pain medication. Plaintiff was embarrassed by the situation and experienced loss of reputation in the community. Court found Defendant’s Charter rights were violated, and damages flow from that injury.

His recovery was complicated by a pre-existing learning disability that made retraining difficult. Liability apportioned 84% to defendant driver, 1% to bar owners, and 15% to plaintiff. Jury award modified by judge.

comments: Libel case involving a business owner with contracts for Toronto area beaches. The trial judge found the statements referred to the company, not the plaintiff personally, and were not libellous toward him. General damages were calculated but not awarded. Appeal dismissed; trial judgment upheld.

Libel. Plaintiff is a business owner with several contracts involving Toronto area beaches. Defendant wrote to Toronto city council and the mayor, arguing that the plaintiff’s contract procurements were suspect, and that a police investigation was warranted. Cited letters in Toronto Life magazine, suggesting that plaintiff used undue influence to procure city contracts. Damages calculated but not awarded. Defendant succeeded on defence of qualified privilege.

Anonymous internet blogger libelled plaintiff lawyer, referring to him as a pedophile, crook, nazi, and imbecile. Plaintiff feared damage to his reputation and professional career. Defendant refused to remove posts or admit their identity.

Plaintiff was sexually touched in a hotel room by defendant uncle in 1975. Compelled to sleep in the nude with defendant overnight. Plaintiff suffers from severe anxiety, hyper-vigilance, and difficulty in forming relationships. Grades began a steep decline following the touching, job prospects were limited.

Defamation. Plaintiff’s nieces alleged that he had sexually assaulted them when they were children. Began warning relatives and sending e-mails describing the sexual assault. The dissent would have affirmed the trial judge’s decision that the appellant is liable for malicious prosecution and would have dismissed the appeal on the quantum of punitive damages.

Plaintiff, a female pedestrian, was struck by a right-turning vehicle. Jury awarded $40,000 in non-pecuniary damages, but the claim was dismissed under s. 267.5(5) of the Insurance Act on defendant’s motion.

case_name: Steven Charles Charlebois v. The Estate of Kris Geoffrey Charlebois (By His Estate Trustee)
comments: Plaintiff was the younger brother of the defendant, who died before proceedings and was represented by his estate trustee. Plaintiff suffered extended sexual abuse by the defendant during childhood and adolescence. Damages were intentionally limited due to estate recovery limits; no claims for past or future income loss or historical treatment expenses were pursued. Pre- and post-judgment interest awarded but unspecified.
Plaintiff entitled to benefits under group insurance policy due to inability to work from major depressive disorder; defendant breached duty of good faith resulting in $10,000 mental distress award.

injuries: major depressive disorder with anxious features

other_damages.description: mental distress damages for breach of duty of good faith
benefit payment under group insurance policy

comments: Sexual assault occurred in 1992. Plaintiff became pregnant and gave birth as a result of the sexual assault. Following the assault, she experienced severe psychological and lifestyle changes, became unable to work, quit sports, developed alcoholism, and withdrew from relationships. Costs awarded to plaintiff. Post-judgment interest at 2% per annum under s. 127 Courts of Justice Act for first quarter of 2021.

other_damages.description: Special damages for costs incurred for raising daughter born of the sexual assault
Subrogated amount from action of Minister of Health

comments: Medical negligence at a maximum-security mental health hospital.
Plaintiffs were treated with various experimental therapy programs involving hallucinogens, sensory deprivation, and physical restraint.

case_name: Waller v. Ryan Brown and Karen Brown
comments: Social worker injured in MVA. Developed chronic pain in shoulder, arm, hip, lower back and knee. Suffered headaches. | Plaintiff suffered debilitating fatigue and psychological issues including PTSD, Major Depressive Disorder, and driving phobia. Cognitive deficits related to fatigue developed and symptoms worsened over time despite many treatments and diagnostic tests. Plaintiff had an excellent work record as a social worker prior to the motor vehicle accident. Judge concluded plaintiff could no longer work.

other_damages.description: plus several periodic payments; pool = $758.50 per annum; physio = $1,004.64 every 3–5 years; travel to family doctor = $6.24 per annum
Investment management fee: 5% of total future award

comments: Plaintiff was front-seat passenger in car that was rear-ended. As a result, she suffered chronic pain in right shoulder, neck, and back, developed depression and anxiety, and her ability to concentrate worsened. Two of her work supervisors gave evidence of her decline.

Judge found the supervisors’ evidence compelling, as well as the emotional testimony the Plaintiff’s father gave. Plaintiff frequently visited pain specialists and paid for treatments out of pocket. Defence had social evidence of Plaintiff enjoying themselves, but judge accepted Plaintiff’s submission that she, like most, posts only positives and hides the negatives.

other_damages.description: future housekeeping per year to age 70
costs of future care per year to age 70

comments: Defendant pushed the plaintiff into a table unprovoked, causing a T11 compression fracture and chronic low back pain. Plaintiff lost her car detailing job, experienced social isolation, depression, suicidal ideation, and stress.

case_name: The Estate of Mary Fleury et al. v. Olayiwola A. Kassim
comments: Dr. Olayiwola Kassim removed the deceased Mary Fleury’s appendix in 2011 during which time he should have discovered Ms. Fleury had cancer, specifically metastatic adenocarcinoma. | Cancer was diagnosed 4 years later and Ms. Fleury died in 2016. Spouse could not work for a period due to depression. Spouse had to assume burden of caring for the deceased’s grandchildren which they had previously taken in. Ms. Fleury acted as the grandchildren’s mother.

case_name: Smith v. Islamic Republic of Iran
comments: Four plaintiffs sued the Islamic Republic of Iran after Flight PS 752 was shot down by the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, killing all 176 on board. The Court found the missile strikes intentional.
Plaintiff suffered injuries related to sexual assault at age 14. Defendant was cousin of Plaintiff’s father. Multiple sexual assaults of a minor.

comments: Plaintiff, a bank mortgage specialist, suffered damages from defamation and libel by the defendant bank. The bank alleged his involvement in mortgage fraud, despite no evidence.

comments: Plaintiff, a business owner and member of the Batchewana First Nation, suffered damages from defamation by a former partner. After separation, the defendant posted false messages on the business's Facebook account, depicting plaintiff as abusive and struggling with addiction.

case_name: Yates v. Iron Horse Corporation and St. Martin
comments: Plaintiff's daughter accused the defendant of sexual harassment, leading to criminal charges and subsequent litigation. After a CBC article, she sued him, prompting a countersuit for defamation and malicious prosecution. Plaintiffs won an anti-SLAPP motion to dismiss. Plaintiff, on a fixed income, experienced significant stress.

other_damages.description: Costs awarded on a full indemnity basis

plaintiffs.comments: Primary plaintiff; experienced significant stress due to litigation and daughter's involvement.
Secondary plaintiff; also affected by the events and litigation stress.

comments: Plaintiffs, lawyers who previously represented the defendant, were defamed by the defendant. | Her Google review accused the defendants of incompetence. She refused to apologize or remove it, leaving it public for nearly three months. The court emphasized that online comments have legal consequences, regardless of the defendant's finances.

case_name: D.S. v. H. Police Services Board
comments: Plaintiff claimed damages for invasion of privacy after a police officer accessed her personal information linked to a murder suspect and falsely accused her of stalking via Facebook. The court dismissed the claim, finding the tort of intrusion upon seclusion not met.

Plaintiff sued defendant for trespass after a payment dispute. Brief use of driveway did not constitute trespass. Any emotional distress experienced by the plaintiff's wife was minimal, required no medical attention, and resolved within weeks. Court dismissed the claim.

comments: False arrest. Multiple taser shots to the genitals while handcuffed. Nervous shock and emotional distress caused by forced detainment. Plaintiff’s damages reduced to $50,000 under jurisdictional limit (Rule 76).

comments: Plaintiff was subjected to false arrest, unreasonable search and seizure, and battery. Plaintiff suffered from exposure to subzero temperatures, swollen cheek, cut lip, pain in his knees, humiliation and embarrassment.
